Plain_Language_Description: Identifier for the tumor sample being analyzed
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: This tells you which patient/sample the variant came from

Plain_Language_Description: Type of structural variant
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: DEL=deletion DUP=duplication INV=inversion BND=translocation/breakend. Most clinically relevant are translocations (BND) affecting cancer genes

Plain_Language_Description: Predicted protein fusion and whether it's in-frame
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Critical for cancer biology - in-frame fusions often create oncogenic fusion proteins. Look for known cancer gene fusions
Typical_Values: Protein Fusion: in frame {GENE1:GENE2}, out of frame, or blank

Plain_Language_Description: First gene affected by the structural variant
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: One of the genes disrupted or fused by this rearrangement. Check if it's a known cancer gene

Plain_Language_Description: Second gene affected by the structural variant
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: The partner gene in a fusion or second breakpoint. Important for identifying known fusion pairs

Plain_Language_Description: Precise location within or near gene1
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Tells you if breakpoint is in an exon (coding) intron or regulatory region. Exonic breaks more likely to disrupt function
Typical_Values: Example: Intron of GENE(+):2Kb before exon 3

Plain_Language_Description: Precise location within or near gene2
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Same as site1 but for the second breakpoint location
Typical_Values: Example: 5'-UTR of GENE(+):3Kb before coding start

Plain_Language_Description: Chromosome of first breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Chromosome where the first break occurred. Chr 1-22 X Y

Plain_Language_Description: Start coordinate of first breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Genomic position (base pair number) where first break starts

Plain_Language_Description: End coordinate of first breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Genomic position where first break ends (usually START+1 for precise breaks)

Plain_Language_Description: Chromosome of second breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Chromosome where the second break occurred. If different from CHROM_A it's a translocation

Plain_Language_Description: Start coordinate of second breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Genomic position where second break starts

Plain_Language_Description: End coordinate of second breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Genomic position where second break ends

Plain_Language_Description: Orientation of the DNA strands at the breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Indicates how the DNA strands are joined. Important for understanding rearrangement mechanism

Plain_Language_Description: Repetitive DNA element at first breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Alu and LINE elements are common. Repeats can cause false positives or indicate mechanism

Plain_Language_Description: Repetitive DNA element at second breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Same as repeat.site1 for second breakpoint

Plain_Language_Description: Which analysis programs detected this variant
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: More callers = higher confidence. brass and manta are most reliable. Format: comma-separated list

Plain_Language_Description: Total number of callers that detected this variant
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Count of supporting programs. 2+ is good 3+ is very confident

Plain_Language_Description: Number of callers where variant passed quality filters
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: More stringent than NumCallers - only counts high-quality calls

Plain_Language_Description: Chromosomal band from Cancer Gene Census
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Cytogenetic band location if variant affects a known cancer gene

Plain_Language_Description: Tumor variant allele fraction from spanning reads (DELLY)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: What fraction of tumor DNA has this variant (spanning read evidence). 0.5 = 50% of cells

Plain_Language_Description: Tumor variant allele fraction from junction reads (DELLY)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Same as SpanVAF but from junction/split reads (more precise evidence)

Plain_Language_Description: Normal variant allele fraction from spanning reads (DELLY)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: VAF in matched normal tissue. Should be 0 for somatic variants. >0.05 suggests germline

Plain_Language_Description: Normal variant allele fraction from junction reads (DELLY)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: VAF in normal from junction reads. Should be 0 for true somatic mutations

Plain_Language_Description: Tumor variant allele fraction from SvABA caller
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Fraction of tumor cells with variant calculated by SvABA assembly method

Plain_Language_Description: Normal variant allele fraction from SvABA caller
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: VAF in normal tissue from SvABA. Should be near 0 for somatic variants

Plain_Language_Description: Tumor variant allele fraction from junction reads (MANTA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Fraction of tumor cells from MANTA split-read evidence

Plain_Language_Description: Number of paired-end reads supporting variant (DELLY)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: How many read-pairs support this SV. Higher = more evidence. Need 3+ for deletions 5+ for translocations

Plain_Language_Description: Number of split-reads supporting variant (DELLY)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Split reads span the exact breakpoint. Very strong evidence. Often lower than PE but more precise

Plain_Language_Description: Paired-read counts in tumor: reference and variant (MANTA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Format: REF,ALT. Example: 106,6 means 106 normal pairs 6 variant pairs

Plain_Language_Description: Split-read counts in tumor: reference and variant (MANTA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Format: REF,ALT. Split reads are highest quality evidence

Plain_Language_Description: Number of tumor reads supporting the variant allele (SvABA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Direct count of reads with the variant. Higher = more confident call

Plain_Language_Description: Number of tumor spanning reads supporting variant (SvABA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Spanning read support from SvABA

Plain_Language_Description: Paired-read counts in normal: reference and variant (MANTA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Format: REF,ALT. ALT should be 0 or very low for somatic

Plain_Language_Description: Split-read counts in normal: reference and variant (MANTA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Format: REF,ALT. ALT should be 0 for true somatic variants

Plain_Language_Description: Number of normal reads supporting the variant allele (SvABA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Should be 0 or very low for somatic variants. High values suggest germline

Plain_Language_Description: Number of normal spanning reads supporting variant (SvABA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Should be low/zero for somatic variants

Plain_Language_Description: Number of tumor read-pairs supporting reference (normal) allele
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Reference evidence in tumor. Used with DV to calculate VAF

Plain_Language_Description: Number of tumor read-pairs supporting variant allele
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Variant-supporting pairs in tumor. DV/(DR+DV) gives approximate VAF

Plain_Language_Description: Number of tumor junction reads supporting reference allele
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Reference junction reads in tumor

Plain_Language_Description: Number of tumor junction reads supporting variant allele
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Variant junction reads in tumor. Independent evidence from split reads

Plain_Language_Description: Number of tumor discordant reads supporting variant (SvABA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Discordant read-pair evidence from SvABA in tumor

Plain_Language_Description: Number of normal read-pairs supporting reference allele
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Reference evidence in normal tissue

Plain_Language_Description: Number of normal read-pairs supporting variant allele
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Should be 0 for somatic. >0 suggests germline or contamination

Plain_Language_Description: Number of normal junction reads supporting reference allele
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Reference junction reads in normal

Plain_Language_Description: Number of normal junction reads supporting variant allele
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Should be 0 for true somatic variants

Plain_Language_Description: Number of normal discordant reads supporting variant (SvABA)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Should be low/zero for somatic variants

Plain_Language_Description: Tumor types where this gene has somatic mutations (Cancer Gene Census)
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Lists cancer types where this gene is known to be somatically mutated. Helps assess clinical relevance

Plain_Language_Description: Cancer syndromes associated with germline mutations in this gene
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Lists hereditary cancer syndromes if this is a known germline cancer gene

Plain_Language_Description: Type of mutation typically seen in this gene in cancer
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Indicates whether gene acts as oncogene (gain-of-function) or tumor suppressor (loss-of-function)

Plain_Language_Description: Known translocation partner genes from Cancer Gene Census
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Lists genes known to fuse with this gene in cancer. Important for identifying recurrent fusions

Plain_Language_Description: Database of Genomic Variants entries at first breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Shows if this region has known benign structural variants in healthy populations. Many entries may indicate common variant

Plain_Language_Description: Database of Genomic Variants entries at second breakpoint
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Same as DGv site1 but for second breakpoint

Plain_Language_Description: Consensus sequence at breakpoint from DELLY assembly
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Actual DNA sequence assembled across the breakpoint. Can reveal insertions or microhomology

Plain_Language_Description: Identifier for the matched normal sample
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: The normal tissue sample used for comparison to identify somatic variants

Plain_Language_Description: Unique identifier for this specific variant call
What_Biologists_Need_to_Know: Universal unique identifier for tracking this exact variant across analyses
